channel.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
channel.description:
I have three open source projects on GitHub that I am slowly working on that I would like to share with the community:
In my spare time, I am developing a new MMORPG adventure game based on the DarkQuest RSC private server framework. I like the game mechanics in RSC and wish to implement them with all new game content. I plan to strip out all RSC game content assets over time and replace them with new sprites, new NPCs, new objects, new items, a new landscape continent to explore, an assortment of all new quests to adventure, and a fully interactive player website to go along with it. The game is open source on GitHub and will remain free to play, both in code and eventually in hosting of a server. I will be removing the subscriber features as I do not believe in monetizing this game to turn a profit whatsoever as this is not proprietary to me, the client is still Jagex's intellectual property, and every community member that has or will contribute to this project should never have their work be exploited for personal monetary gain. If and when I have the money to set up a DDoS shielded game server for the public to play on, I will pay for it out of my own pocket and the administration will be invisible to regular players to allow complete anarchy to reign and plenty of good clan fights to result from player vs player disputes. Experience will be tweaked in several areas to reduce the need to grind and bot but still let players accomplish what they want to keep their interest.
A website has been set up for this project for anyone to check out but a public server will not be available for the foreseeable future. I will run a test server for developers but only whitelisted IPs will be able to connect to it. http://www.wolfkingdom.net
[b][url=https://github.com/Cleako/Wolf-Kingdom-Website]Cleako/Wolf-Kingdom-Website[/url][/b]
[ul][li]This is a PHP website built to run on IIS7+ web server. Pages might not load right with Apache. I need to work more on this to fix it still.[/li] [li]This includes a main website for the player management interface and a PHPBB forum with a bug tracker mod for players and developers to submit tickets.[/li] [li]The player management interface works well but needs the password changing function to be added. I would also like to add an online friends list along the right side for logged in game friends.[/li] [li]The database is shared with the Wolf-Kingdom-Server project and can be found in that project. The database file is named "lupus_regnum.sql"[/li] [li]Forum administrator account "root" with password set as "password" has been registered on the forum.[/li] [li]The in-game player created under the "root" username is named "testing" with password "testing".[/li][/ul]
[b][url=https://github.com/Cleako/Wolf-Kingdom-Server]Cleako/Wolf-Kingdom-Server[/url][/b]
[ul][li]This is a clean export of the HEAD revision from Peeter's DarkQuest subversion repository on Assembla.com.[/li] [li]The database is shared with the Wolf-Kingdom-Website project and can be found in this project. The database file is named "lupus_regnum.sql"[/li] [li]The in-game admin player is "testing" with password "testing".[/li] [li]Player ranks are set under the rsca2_players.group_id column. Admin=1, Mod=2, Pmod=3, Player=0[/li] [li]Password hashes are SHA1. A goal is to make them SHA512 or better in strength.[/li] [li]ls.conf and gs.conf contain many variables that will need to be set.[/li] [li]This project has been imported into NetBeans but can still be run through terminal or command prompt with Apache ant.[/li] [li]There are a large amount of new features that I have from the Lupus Regnum project that I will be merging with this over time. The main focus will be maintaining clean and stable code.[/li][/ul]
[url=https://github.com/Cleako/Wolf-Kingdom-Client][b]Cleako/Wolf-Kingdom-Client[/b][/url]
[ul][li]This is a clean export of the HEAD revision from Peeter's DarkQuest subversion repository on Assembla.com.[/li] [li]This project has been imported into NetBeans but can still be run through terminal or command prompt with Apache ant.[/li] [li]This is a functional webclient with webclient.html included. Client jar must be signed before it will run. NetBeans can self sign the jar during build.[/li] [li]There are a large amount of new features that I have from the Lupus Regnum project that I will be merging with this over time. The main focus will be maintaining clean and stable code.[/li][/ul]
Pre-existing features that will be added:
[ul][li]Pet summoning[/li] [li]Pet following[/li] [li]Pet capturing[/li] [li]Fatigue becoming energy level (reversed at 100% down to 0%)[/li] [li]Trusting Sean Crooks quest[/li] [li]Spawn Mystenhaven portal object spell[/li] [li]PVP inhibit cast spell[/li] [li]MD5CHECKSUM client cache loader[/li] [li]Thieving skill[/li] [li]Functional dwarf cannons[/li] [li]Custom menu sprites[/li] [li]Custom building texture sprites[/li] [li]Custom tree texture sprites[/li] [li]Custom hit splash sprites[/li][/ul]
Lastly, I will be recording several video tutorials on how to do everything with this project for newbies to get up to speed. I will host the videos on Vimeo.com for HD playback.

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @cleako cleako
item.description:
@cleako wrote:

Wolf-Kingdom-Tools updates:

[ul][li]Refactored project name and renamed .rscd cache file extentions to .wk.[/li]
[li]Corrected error in ground texture numbering that was preventing dark browns greater than 128 to be selected when they can normally.[/li]
[li]Changed config to load landscape.wk from %USERPROFILE%\CONF_DIR\CACHE_NAME to save time when testing changes.[/li]
[li]Added cache loader to 3D Landscape Editor[/li]
[li]Will now download any missing cache files just like the game client does. If local files change, it will not pull from server fresh copies until the server cache’s MD5CHECKSUM.txt is updated. This allows easy landscape development and testing between editor, client, and server.[/li][/ul]

Wolf-Kingdom-Server updates:

[ul][li]Configured Landscape.wk to load from client cache[/li]
[li]To guarantee Landscape.wk loads on the server the same version that the
clients are using, the server now pulls Landscape.wk from
%USERPROFILE%\CONF_DIR\CACHE_NAME. This speeds up landscape development
and avoids manual file copying after each save when testing landscape
changes. Will add a cache loader if Landscape.wk is missing next.[/li][/ul]

Wolf-Kingdom-Client updates:

[ul][li]Renamed .rscd cache file extentions to .wk[/li]
[li]Cleaned up cache loading progress[/li][/ul]

To do:

[ul][li]Add cache loader for Landscape.wk to the game server.[/li]
[li]Remove calls to unneeded cache files in 3D Landscape Editor[/li]
[li]Find source of 2D Landscape Editor and implement (x, y) coords translation in 3D Landscape Editor for quick testing in game client[/li]
[li]Implement minimap compass into 3D Landscape Editor for WSAD movement[/li][/ul]

Bugs to fix:

[ul][li]Log off does not return pet to crystal but removes pet. Set login loop for swapping empty crystals with full crystal spawn items but only half of the items return each time and rest are deleted.[/li]
[li]Pets should be saved in db player cache.[/li]
[li]Pets should spawn if they were previously removed by the server due to logout or unable to follow owner.[/li]
[li]Pet spawning could be better as a spell instead of items.[/li]
[li]Copies of NPCs used as pets should not be aggressive or attackable.[/li]
[li]Owners should be able to control a pet for staying put and wandering or following.[/li]
[li]Pets should be able to attack NPCs if owner enables it.[/li][/ul]

Read full topic

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:20, topic:533995”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=652789.msg4377546#msg4377546 date=1382489137]
I’m pretty sure SHA-512, while less secure, isn’t a walk in the park to crack.
[/quote]By crack I just meant brute-forcing. It doesn’t take much longer (if at all) than MD5 or SHA1 to compute because it isn’t supposed to.[/quote]

I noticed this the other day when I was cracking a local wifi. You can brute force SHA-512 easily and if you don’t have the computing power you can pay a website to do it for you.

Read full topic

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:15, topic:533995”]Password-wise, any hash by itself isn’t a good idea. ALWAYS use a salt, even if it’s just the username (sha512(username+sha512(password)) or something like that, which renders you invulnerable to a rainbow tables attack. Secondly, whatever hashing you go with should take place on the client side, so that the server never receives a plaintext password in the first place.[/quote]With Bcrypt you’re required to use a salt. Even salting your SHA512 hashed passwords it’s still fairly easy to crack, you just aren’t suseptable to rainbow table attacks. And if you let your client handle hashing, they can do whatever they want with it before it’s sent to you. You can’t be sure it’s a valid hash.

We had a good discussion however many days ago about using bcrypt instead which, after further reading, I concluded was the superior approach. However this is just a server emulator so I doubt anyone is going to have the resources, or desire to apply them, to password cracking.
You wouldn't even need any special resources to do it. Sure if you had a GPU farm you'd be able to get all the passwords very fast, but it certainly isn't necessary, especially considering the low amounts of players on these servers.

Read full topic

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy

@lothy wrote:

However this is just a server emulator so I doubt anyone is going to have the resources, or desire to apply them, to password cracking.

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @cleako cleako
item.description:
@cleako wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Password-wise, any hash by itself isn’t a good idea. ALWAYS use a salt, even if it’s just the username (sha512(username+sha512(password)) or something like that, which renders you invulnerable to a rainbow tables attack. Secondly, whatever hashing you go with should take place on the client side, so that the server never receives a plaintext password in the first place.

I like that approach. The username as a salt would make generating rainbow tables virtually impossible to generate for an entire database but could leave individual users at risk of a custom rainbow table if that was all that was done in theory. I was curious about collisions and found this explanation very enlightening:

http://stackoverflow.com/a/4948393

A note on hashes for passwords:

A key feature of cryptographic hash functions is that they should be very fast to create, and very difficult/slow to reverse (so much so that it’s practically impossible). This poses a problem with passwords. If you store sha512(password), you’re not doing a thing to guard against rainbow tables or brute force attacks. Remember, the hash function was designed for speed. So it’s trivial for an attacker to just run a dictionary through the hash function and test each result.

Adding a salt helps matters since it adds a bit of unknown data to the hash. So instead of finding anything that matches md5(foo), they need to find something that when added to the known salt produces md5(foo.salt) (which is very much harder to do). But it still doesn’t solve the speed problem since if they know the salt it’s just a matter of running the dictionary through.

So, there are ways of dealing with this. One popular method is called key strengthening (or key stretching). Basically, you iterate over a hash many times (thousands usually). This does two things. First, it slows down the runtime of the hashing algorithm significantly. Second, if implemented right (passing the input and salt back in on each iteration) actually increases the entropy (available space) for the output, reducing the chances of collisions. A trivial implementation is:

var hash = password + salt; for (var i = 0; i < 5000; i++) { hash = sha512(hash + password + salt); }
There are other, more standard implementations such as PBKDF2, BCrypt. But this technique is used by quite a few security related systems (such as PGP, WPA, Apache and OpenSSL).

The bottom line, hash(password) is not good enough. hash(password + salt) is better, but still not good enough… Use a stretched hash mechanism to produce your password hashes…

Another note on trivial stretching

Do not under any circumstances feed the output of one hash directly back into the hash function:

hash = sha512(password + salt); for (i = 0; i < 1000; i++) { hash = sha512(hash); // <-- Do NOT do this! }
The reason for this has to do with collisions. Remember that all hash functions have collisions because the possible output space (the number of possible outputs) is smaller than then input space. To see why, let’s look at what happens. To preface this, let’s make the assumption that there’s a 0.001% chance of collision from sha1() (it’s much lower in reality, but for demonstration purposes).

hash1 = sha1(password + salt);
Now, hash1 has a probability of collision of 0.001%. But when we do the next hash2 = sha1(hash1);, all collisions of hash1 automatically become collisions of hash2. So now, we have hash1’s rate at 0.001%, and the 2nd sha1 call adds to that. So now, hash2 has a probability of collision of 0.002%. That’s twice as many chances! Each iteration will add another 0.001% chance of collision to the result. So, with 1000 iterations, the chance of collision jumped from a trivial 0.001% to 1%. Now, the degradation is linear, and the real probabilities are far smaller, but the effect is the same (an estimation of the chance of a single collision with md5 is about 1/(2^128) or 1/3e38. While that seems small, thanks to the birthday attack it’s not really as small as it seems).

Instead, by re-appending the salt and password each time, you’re re-introducing data back into the hash function. So any collisions of any particular round are no longer collisions of the next round. So:

hash = sha512(password + salt); for (i = 0; i < 1000; i++) { hash = sha512(hash + password + salt); } Has the same chance of collision as the native sha512 function. Which is what you want. Use that instead…

Read full topic

@moparisthebest wrote:

Password-wise, any hash by itself isn’t a good idea. ALWAYS use a salt, even if it’s just the username (sha512(username+sha512(password)) or something like that, which renders you invulnerable to a rainbow tables attack. Secondly, whatever hashing you go with should take place on the client side, so that the server never receives a plaintext password in the first place.

This topic serves to inform the public about this open source project and to request anyone who might be interested to contribute to the project on GitHub to do so.

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:7, topic:533995”]I don’t think SHA-512 is considered broken (i.e., it’s still considered a reasonable choice and, in practice, will provide protection against most threat vectors).
With that said though, thanks for linking that stackexchange article.

EDIT: Found this: http://www.unlimitednovelty.com/2012/03/dont-use-bcrypt.html and http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4433216/password-encryption-pbkdf2-using-sha512-x-1000-vs-bcrypt
It may be the case that you can do one better than bcrypt.[/quote]I never said SHA512 was broken, it just isn’t appropriate for storing passwords (on its own). PBKDF2 or bcrypt would be ideal solutions.

Read full topic

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I don’t think SHA-512 is considered broken (i.e., it’s still considered a reasonable choice and, in practice, will provide protection against most threat vectors).
With that said though, thanks for linking that stackexchange article.

EDIT: Found this: http://www.unlimitednovelty.com/2012/03/dont-use-bcrypt.html and http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4433216/password-encryption-pbkdf2-using-sha512-x-1000-vs-bcrypt
It may be the case that you can do one better than bcrypt.

Read full topic

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:5, topic:533995”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=652789.msg4373872#msg4373872 date=1381521883]

[quote author=cleako link=topic=652789.msg4373871#msg4373871 date=1381521842]
SHA512 is the goal. DarkQuest/RSCA is SHA1. Yet another thing on the list to work on.
[/quote]Still isn’t appropriate for passwords.
[/quote]How so?[/quote]http://security.stackexchange.com/questions/4781/do-any-security-experts-recommend-bcrypt-for-password-storage/6415#6415

It’s also summed up nicely in the next post.

bcrypt has a significant advantage over a simply salted SHA-256 hash: bcrypt uses a modified key setup algorithm which is timely quite expensive. This is called key strengthening, and makes a password more secure against brute force attacks, since the attacker now needs a lot more time to test each possible key.

Read full topic

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

utilizes SHA1 player password encryption
Don't use a fast, general hashing algorithm for passwords storage. Consider [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bcrypt]bcrypt[/url] or something similar.

Read full topic

item.title: Wolf-Kingdom projects on GitHub
item.dc:creator: @cleako cleako
item.description:
@cleako wrote:

I have three open source projects on GitHub that I am slowly working on that I would like to share with the community:

In my spare time, I am developing a new MMORPG adventure game based on the DarkQuest RSC private server framework. I like the game mechanics in RSC and wish to implement them with all new game content. I plan to strip out all RSC game content assets over time and replace them with new sprites, new NPCs, new objects, new items, a new landscape continent to explore, an assortment of all new quests to adventure, and a fully interactive player website to go along with it. The game is open source on GitHub and will remain free to play, both in code and eventually in hosting of a server. I will be removing the subscriber features as I do not believe in monetizing this game to turn a profit whatsoever as this is not proprietary to me, the client is still Jagex’s intellectual property, and every community member that has or will contribute to this project should never have their work be exploited for personal monetary gain. If and when I have the money to set up a DDoS shielded game server for the public to play on, I will pay for it out of my own pocket and the administration will be invisible to regular players to allow complete anarchy to reign and plenty of good clan fights to result from player vs player disputes. Experience will be tweaked in several areas to reduce the need to grind and bot but still let players accomplish what they want to keep their interest.

A website has been set up for this project for anyone to check out but a public server will not be available for the foreseeable future. I will run a test server for developers but only whitelisted IPs will be able to connect to it.
http://www.wolfkingdom.net

Cleako/Wolf-Kingdom-Website

[ul][li]This is a PHP website built to run on IIS7+ web server. Pages might not load right with Apache. I need to work more on this to fix it still.[/li]
[li]This includes a main website for the player management interface and a PHPBB forum with a bug tracker mod for players and developers to submit tickets.[/li]
[li]The player management interface works well but needs the password changing function to be added. I would also like to add an online friends list along the right side for logged in game friends.[/li]
[li]The database is shared with the Wolf-Kingdom-Server project and can be found in that project. The database file is named “lupus_regnum.sql”[/li]
[li]Forum administrator account “root” with password set as “password” has been registered on the forum.[/li]
[li]The in-game player created under the “root” username is named “testing” with password “testing”.[/li][/ul]

Cleako/Wolf-Kingdom-Server

[ul][li]This is a clean export of the HEAD revision from Peeter’s DarkQuest subversion repository on Assembla.com.[/li]
[li]The database is shared with the Wolf-Kingdom-Website project and can be found in this project. The database file is named “lupus_regnum.sql”[/li]
[li]The in-game admin player is “testing” with password “testing”.[/li]
[li]Player ranks are set under the rsca2_players.group_id column. Admin=1, Mod=2, Pmod=3, Player=0[/li]
[li]Password hashes are SHA1. A goal is to make them SHA512 or better in strength.[/li]
[li]ls.conf and gs.conf contain many variables that will need to be set.[/li]
[li]This project has been imported into NetBeans but can still be run through terminal or command prompt with Apache ant.[/li]
[li]There are a large amount of new features that I have from the Lupus Regnum project that I will be merging with this over time. The main focus will be maintaining clean and stable code.[/li][/ul]

Cleako/Wolf-Kingdom-Client

[ul][li]This is a clean export of the HEAD revision from Peeter’s DarkQuest subversion repository on Assembla.com.[/li]
[li]This project has been imported into NetBeans but can still be run through terminal or command prompt with Apache ant.[/li]
[li]This is a functional webclient with webclient.html included. Client jar must be signed before it will run. NetBeans can self sign the jar during build.[/li]
[li]There are a large amount of new features that I have from the Lupus Regnum project that I will be merging with this over time. The main focus will be maintaining clean and stable code.[/li][/ul]

Pre-existing features that will be added:

[ul][li]Pet summoning[/li]
[li]Pet following[/li]
[li]Pet capturing[/li]
[li]Fatigue becoming energy level (reversed at 100% down to 0%)[/li]
[li]Trusting Sean Crooks quest[/li]
[li]Spawn Mystenhaven portal object spell[/li]
[li]PVP inhibit cast spell[/li]
[li]MD5CHECKSUM client cache loader[/li]
[li]Thieving skill[/li]
[li]Functional dwarf cannons[/li]
[li]Custom menu sprites[/li]
[li]Custom building texture sprites[/li]
[li]Custom tree texture sprites[/li]
[li]Custom hit splash sprites[/li][/ul]

Lastly, I will be recording several video tutorials on how to do everything with this project for newbies to get up to speed. I will host the videos on Vimeo.com for HD playback.

Read full topic
